Award.AwardTitle: NSF/FDA SIR: Non-invasive assessment of neuromechanical outcomes from next generation peripheral nerve implants

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Shah, Sameer
Proposal Number: 1541908

The PI proposes to develop advanced evaluation criteria for peripheral nerve electrodes, which may alter nerve structure, biomechanics and physiological function, using non-invasive imaging modalities.

Micro-CT and ultra short echo time MRI (UTE) will be used to study the structure-function effects of cuff electrodes (CEs) and Utah Slanted Electrode Arrays (USEAs) placed on the sciatic nerve between the hip and the knee (mid thigh) of rats. The training received by the graduate student and undergraduate student working on the project at the FDA will be excellent. Each research Objective describes experimental methods involved that would be appropriate for high school students as well as undergraduate and graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A variety of new biomedical devices have been designed to interface with peripheral nerves, to enhance motor and sensory function (movement and sensation). In this project, we developed new imaging approaches to evaluate the geometry and structural integrity of peripheral nerves, to understand their response to the implantation of nerve interfacing devices.

The intellectual merit of this project was to develop and test methods from three different nerve imaging modalities, and assess the utility of each modality. We used Micro computed tomography (micro-CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and ultrasound to image nerves. Micro-CT generated high resolution images of nerve structure fairly rapidly (<20 minutes per 3D image), but required nerves to be removed from the body and also required soaking in a contrast agent prior to imaging. Thus, it has utility for evaluating nerve structure in animal models, but would not be very useful clinically. Ultrashort echo time (UTE)-MRI allowed us to visualize nerve structure and geometry with high-contrast and sensitivity, in animal and in humans without required dissection, and also non-invasively and without a need for a contrast agent. However, scan times were often lengthy to achieve high resolution. Thus, there may be clinical utility for this modality, but perhaps only if a detailed structural assessment is required (i.e., not for run of the mill nerve problems). High frequency ultrasound was very rapid, and offered moderate resolution, though not as high as UTE-MRI. This may be an ideal clinical imaging modality, when a general structural assessment of nerve is required.

Broader impacts of this project are two-fold. From a basic science perpsective, we have a better understanding of what biological structures are responsible for generating specific imaging signals. This has high value in developing new imaging methods and also interpreting acquired images. From a clinical perspective, our methods will be valuable in diagnosing various nerve injuries and neuropathies as well as tracking the progression of nerve structure and mechanical function during disease progression or in response to treatment. Such methods are sorely lacking. 

This award also required significant interaction of project staff, including the principal investigator, with the United States FDA. This provided excellent insight into the criteria by which the FDA evaluates devices, and also spawned new applied scientific collaborations related to nerve device implantation and evaluation, which are ongoing. Several scientists were trained at the graduate and postdoctoral levels during the project period, and outreach activities were performed with local elementary schools, to promote science and technology education.

Modified by: Sameer B Shah

Images (1 of )
  • Ultrasound effectively reveals nerve geometry and structure. Longitudinal (left) and cross-sectional (right) views of a human median nerve in vivo, during wrist extension from a neutral configuration. Note distal gliding and deformation of the nerve (narrowing). Diameter shown by white bars.
    Dr. Eric Chang
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Sameer B Shah
    Nerve Ultrasound
  • (A-B) Neural structures in a human median nerve imaged at 11.7T. (A) magnitude reconstruction image. (B) phase map. The perineurium is light in (A) and dark in (B). (C) Diabetic median nerve has structural differences, including wavy perineurial boundaries (arrow).
    Dr. Graeme Bydder
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Sameer B Shah
    MRI of Nerve
